captions.text:
Interstellar is a visual masterpiece, but
the most spectacular aspect of the movie is

that those jaw dropping shots of black holes
and wormholes are the most realistic depictions

of these phenomena man has ever created. Thanks
to a $200 million budget only a proven blockbuster

filmmaker can command, Director Christopher
Nolan’s team had the resources to create

impeccably detailed computer generated simulations
of space-time events that had previously only

existed in highly complex equations. To achieve
this task, Nolan’s visual effects director

Paul Franklin used the mathematical genius
of leading astrophysicist Kip Thorne to generate

algorithms that guided the effects software.
In fact, it was the astrophysicist himself

who conceptualized the film along with producer
Lynda Obst, who Thorne worked with on 1997’s

Contact. Thorne’s passionate about explaining
the mind-bending ideas of relativity to the

general public and was thrilled when he saw
the final result. The visuals are so powerful,

so accurate, that Thorne’s planning on publishing
two academic journal articles based on the

computer renderings of a black hole used in
the film, which led to a new scientific discovery:

that light temporarily trapped around the
black hole produced an unexpectedly complex

fingerprint pattern and a glowing accretion
disk that appeared above, below, and in front

of the black hole. “I never expected that,”
Thorne says, “it was just amazing.” No

one knew exactly what a black hole would look
like until they actually built one for the

film. Some of the single frames in these sequences
of the film took 100 hours to render. The

entire movie is 800 terabytes of data. Another
thing that makes a lot of the science behind

the film realistic is the script. Steven Spielberg,
who was originally set to direct, hired Chris

Nolan’s brother, the screenwriter Jonathan
Nolan, to write the movie. Nolan worked on

it for four years, even studying relativity
at the California Institute of Technology

to learn the science. When Christopher Nolan
took over as director, he emphasized the human

element of the picture and even codenamed
the film “Flora’s Letter” because it’s

essentially a letter to his daughter, says
star Jessica Chastain. To film the scenes

set on a dying, dusty Earth, the production
planted a 500-acre cornfield in rural Alberta.

Then they burned it all down in a "manufactured
apocalypse." Nolan was inspired by Stanley

Kubrick’s 2001, A Space Odyssey in many
ways, including “the one powerful Image”

idea, which led to Nolan’s ambitious use
of longer shots. Like Nolan’s batman trilogy

before it, Interstellar is shot on 70mm Imax
film and is - according to the director - “all

about the theatrical experience, getting audiences
to see it as an experience in the theatre

with other people.” That’s why the movie
will open to the widest ever release for a

film, in 760 Imax theatres around the planet.
Thanks for watching. Share this video if you

thought it was interesting and make sure you
subscribe to The Daily Conversation for our

next informative, daily video. Click on the
screen to check out our video running down

the most promising energy sources of the future
and interesting facts about the last highly
successful space-themed film, Gravity.

limits of our dimension.  If you run a bushing tool bit through a 2d world, 
it becomes both a circle and a square.  Here's another example.  A 3d being

I liked the film for it's accurateness (most of the time, don't hate me) 
and the stunning visuals and the fact that it had an interesting story 
because 90 minutes full of one person floating through space is kinda lame.

I agree with you on the happy end problem but the truth is that most people 
prefer seeing movies with happy ends. I personally liked the ending and how 
it went back to the "love ist the strongest force" idea.
comments.author: maxstone2210

comments.text:
+maxstone2210 Doctor Who for the win.

But in all seriousness, the tesseract and the future humans was a major 
asspull on the film maker's part. It essentially gave Cooper his happy 
ending. It ruins what was an essentially real and difficult dilemma. Stay 
on Earth with your loved ones as all of humanity dies, or go into space and 
find a new homeworld for the new generation of humans you have in 
incubation. The movie uses a deus ex machina so that Earth is saved, Cooper 
lives, Murph lived a full and happy life, and they all get a new homeworld. 
Win-win for everybody!


If a scenario like this was to happened, hoping for future humans to solve 
our problems with paradoxes is not going to save anybody.
comments.author: RyuSpike

after each other. In reality time is more like a big ball full of wibbly 
wobbly timey wimey ... stuff.

For example, using aliens as the origin would have been logically 
consistent and possible.

comments.text:
+Paul M Edwards Also, +James Harleman didn't seem to have a big a problem 
with The LEGO Movie as I did. I was offended by the message inherent in 
that film's relationship between its symbolic God the Father and God the 
Son, and found it to be *one* of the things at the root of everything wrong 
with our culture. It also introduced a second thing radically wrong with 
our culture: the "everyone is special" belief. I totally disagree with it, 
or at least how our culture understands and applies it. That film left a 
bad taste in my mouth.

(I just skimmed the review, looking to get a quick-view of his take on 
these two things.)

comments.author: GLITCHED MATRIX

comments.text:
I was thinking about the multidimensional aspect of black holes before I 
seen the movie. If mass were coordinates the mass of something would go up 
in higher dimensions so it's natural to think about black holes.

All this mention of being stretched in a black hole seems wrong. This is a 
special relativity thing and also a smoothness thing. You would get shorter 
not longer in a black hole. You are accelerating smoothly. One point in 
space isn't going to pull you down 1000 times harder than the point above 
it. And I doubt you would die, in fact I'm betting you would be around till 
the end of the universe.

There is a video of a super massive black hole swallowing a sun. It doesn't 
get stretched when it swings into it. You would expect to see one very big 
sun. Although the gasses get swung out into space and it looks like it's 
getting stretched but those are the gasses left over after the sun gets 
swallowed.

Maybe we are in a black hole right now. ﻿

more cameras and sensors through first?﻿

comments.author: vinzhell

comments.text:
+vinzhell No, they didn't create the animations with the express intention 
of illustrating the phenomena expected, they created computer models that 
attempted to simulate the expected conditions and observed how the 
computer's projections showed it to look, it was at that point they began 
to embellish upon the images to make them more visually striking.
The calculations came first, then the model was made, then the computer 
showed how it would likely appear, then the image was polished over.
And the film made a large profit whilst attempting to promote scientific 
understanding and enthusiasm among a population that sorely fucking needs 
more of both (though their success in the latter endeavor is up for debate) 
if you believe that to be money badly spent then you're simply... well... a

No, first they were expected by general relativity, then we observed 
phenomena consistent with what such an object would do to it's 
surroundings, which we took as collaborating evidence (not proof) for the 
concept, and now we've spent a great deal of money simulating them we can 
refine our projections of how such a thing would look.

As a layman in astrophysics i was simply blown away by that movie. And as a 
hobby (science) fiction writer, i am excited about what our future will

comments.author: OldGamer

comments.text:
I loved the film, and only had one minor gripe about it.  It took a 
multi-stage rocket booster to get the spacecraft off the Earth, but it was 
able to land on a couple of other planets and take off from them again with 
relative ease.  When it landed the first time I wondered how they were 
going to get back up again.  Maybe the booster was used not because it was 
needed, but to conserve fuel for the other take-offs that would come later.

The visuals were amazing, as was the whole film.  Anyone who hasn't seen it 
yet ought to do so.  I really thought I was going to be disappointed again, 
but this film demonstrates how sci-fi needs to be done.﻿
comments.author: Keira Churchill

the physics behind the movie may be accurate... but the movie itself is 
full of stupid things. like the nearest star is 1000 light years away... 
like getting close (and inside!) to a super-massive black hole without 
being stretched by space-time distortion and melted by the super hot gases 
that orbit around the black hole. like the paradox about how the 
protagonist get to gargantua for the first time, when no wormhole near 
saturn can lead humans there, in order to start the human kind 
transcendence into the 5th dimension, and so on. bottom line: the 
meticulous research of how a black hole would look like in reality, is 
spoiled by the sheer amount of crap in the movie.﻿

comments.author: MikiMaki76

comments.text:
+MikiMaki76 Spaghettification is effectively non-existent around a super 
massive black hole for something as small a Cooper, or even a ship, as 
tidal forces are tiny for things that size.  Cooper would have been to be 
ridiculously close to the singularity for it to take effect and by the time 
he would be there, for all intents and purposes, he was not in the black 
hole anymore.
comments.author: anonymousgamer

comments.text:
+Zero the Faceless
ok, let's see:
1) the gas/matter density around the bh is likely to be huge, due to the 
huge gravitational field. so Cooper was bound to lose speed quickly.
2)  when plants developed on earth, there was no oxygen at all in the 
atmosphere. so plants using oxygen at night time is an evolutionary thing, 
a relatively recent thing, not a strategy plants has always used, but 
something that was developed during billions of years. therefore, your 
example is flawed, as you assumed that plants always used oxygen, but 
that's not true. as I said over and over again, 1+1=2 and 2<>1+1 it is 
simply not possible, whether you call it loop or paradox, it's a plot hole 
pure and simple.
comments.author: MikiMaki76

comments.text:
+MikiMaki76
1) Very well, point taken, he would lose speed over time. How fast he would 
lose speed is questionable however. Ranger seemed to be made 
aerodynamically, resistance wouldn't be as enormous as you suggest, and 
we're talking about the black hole, which as you pointed time and time 
again has so strong gravitational field that light cannot escape, i don't 
think he'd have enoguh time to lose all his speed if he was going in fast 
enough. I haven't seen precise calculations, but possibility is enough to 
suspend my disbelief.
2) Even if plants didn't use oxygen to brieve as you suggest it would have 
been mistake on my side, not a paradox. But i assure you it's not a 
mistake. Plants use carbon dioxyde for photosynthesis, not breathing. and 
byproduct of this is oxygen but plants still use oxygen to breathe. When 
there is no sunlight, and photosynthesis is impossible, the plants breathe 
oxygen just like any other living thing, and even when there is sunlight 
plants still breathe oxygen, but globally the oxygen created from 
photosynthesis is much grater than the one plant uses to breathe. Just a 
little biology lesson for you.
Back to the topic what is the actuall paradox you keep pointing out? You 
keep pointing at the loop and calling it paradox. We used the wormhole to 
survive, then after huge ammount of time we mastered gravity, and 
5-dimentional space alowing us to create the wormhole, what ensured our 
survival. You're not saying that there is something wrong with the 
equation, you're saying that the equation shouldn't be there to begin with. 
I say that as long as all elements of the equation are present it still 
stands. You don't know how actual time-travel would work, so you cannot 
claim that this one is wrong until you poit out definite flaw or 
contradiction. This movie assumes that time travel was part of timeline to 
begin with, and that's one possibility. I've seen several paradoxes 
involving time travel, but while it comes close to onthological paradox, 
when object or information exist because of time travel, without being 
created it comes only as far as close.
comments.author: Zero the Faceless

comments.text:
+SteelFyire
"Gargantua's accretion disk is "cold and anemic" ok, next time we will see 
as explanation that a black hole has no gravity at all
"experience fatal spaghetification, with a sufficiently massive black hole" 
you would experience spaghettification later, after chasing the event 
horizon for a while, since space will get farther from you as you sink 
toward the singularity
comments.author: MikiMaki76

comments.text:
+Zero the Faceless
very briefly:
1) inertial speed is kept intact only in perfect vacuum. near a black hole 
there is no atmosphere like on earth, but is still full of superhot gasses 
and other particles, so Cooper detached from the other ship, would quickly 
lose speed and sink into the bh like a ship sink into the sea.
2) following your example "Plants use oxygen to brieve, but without plants 
there is no oxygen, because plants create oxygen as well. Is that a 
paradox?" well YES, it's a paradox, because plants DO NOT use oxygen to 
breathe, but carbon dioxide (co2). oxygen is a side product of the 
reaction, like co2 is for us.
there is no way you can explain how 1+1=2 but 2<> 1+1, because it is simply 
impossible. it's a plot hole, pure and simple.
comments.author: MikiMaki76

comments.text:
+MikiMaki76  I watched the movie and i liked it. And unlike you i remember 
them saying that this is gentle singularity, which means that tidal forces 
near event horizon are weaker than normal making slipping into hole 
possible, sure it was rough like hell, but not impossible. This was 
explained in the movie, and as far as my understanding of physics go, it 
wasn't wrong. and like i mentioned, what happesn AFTER getting through 
event horizon is speculative. Physics we knew 300 years ago goes out of the 
window with speed close to light speed, it's not impossible that physics we 
know today goes out of the window when gravity is so strong that even light 
can escape. No means of checking it, therefore it's open to speculation.
As i already mentioned spaceships do not stop or lose speed when they run 
out of fuel. He sped up the Endurance when ranger was still attached, so 
both ranger and endurance had the same speed, and like you said ranger 
detached AFTER speeding up endurance. Lack of fuel adds nothing to the 
equation, because he had speed already.
Plants use oxygen to brieve, but without plants there is no oxygen, because 
plants create oxygen as well. Is that a paradox? No. As long as both sides 
of the equation are present, everything is fine. Humans transcending would 
be impossible without wormhole, so they created wormhole in order to be 
able to transcend. If the wormhole was already there, allowed humans to 
transcend, and then future humans from the future destroyed the wormhole in 
the past that would be paradox, because without the wormhole, they would be 
unable to transcend to destroy it. But since both wormhole and future 
humans exist at certain points of time the timeline is sustained. You are 
thinking of seperate timelines, when one timeline must exist before the 
time travel and time travel can alter other timelines, but that one 
possible scenario of time travel, the other when time travel was part of a 
timeline from the begginning, is what i called closed time loop, and that 
scenario was used in the movie. No confirmed real-life time travel happened 
so far, so we cannot know for sure how it exacly works.
comments.author: Zero the Faceless

comments.text:
+Zero the Faceless
did you see the movie? if you did, then you didn't get it very well, or 
your grasp of logic and physics is very limited.
he was running out of fuel, so he let himself sink into the bh to let the 
other crew member carry on with the mission of colonization of a new 
planet. I'm not going to explain once more that non even light can escape 
the gravitational field of the bh when too close to it. light bends to 
gravity, and if light does, the human body  won't stand a chance. the tidal 
forces near a bh are simply too much to withstand and matter is ripped 
apart and disintegrated. period.
the paradox it's explained inside the tesserac: gravity can cross 
space-time and change the past; but you cannot change something that does 
not exists. if the humans NEVER arrived to gargantua at one point in the 
past, the event of human transcendence could have never taken place, 
because of logic. the wormhole is there because of human transcendence, but 
human transcendence is possible only thanks to the wormhole... that is 
called PARADOX.
beside, the movie is full of plot holes and nonsense. I'm not wasting 
anymore time talking about nonsense.
comments.author: MikiMaki76

mysterious order, which it does not comprehend but only dimly suspects.”

comments.text:
How a movie #Interstellar produced the most ultra-realistic depictions of 
scientific phenomenon that man has ever created, along with gripping and 
well thought out speculative depictions and excellent human and personal 
drama.     Black Holes, Worm Holes, Relativity, Space Travel, Zero-G, 
Climate Change, alien worlds, artificial intelligence, and more.

Take your elementary & higher aged kids for a field trip (with some 
preparation to know what they will be looking at) and if it sparks 
something in them it will be well worth the risk of it not being a "kids" 
movie.

See this youtube clip for some facts about how they made some of the 
scenes.﻿

were about to be hit became extremely shallow because of the enormous wave 
that was coming.

comments.author: stefania1171

comments.text:
+stefania1171 I'm not sure the human race is any less threatened than 
usual-as always, a gamma ray burst or massive asteroid impact could wipe us 
out-but in the long term, humans will have to spread out into space if they 
want to survive. Nuclear weapons (which I assume you're referring to), as 
scary as they are, do more to deter war than start it, and even a full 
scale nuclear exchange between the United States and Russia (probably) 
wouldn't completely wipe us out.

That aside, just because you can't see any immediate value of a particular 
discipline of science, it doesn't mean that field is worthless; the nature 
of the compact post stellar bodies that you insist are not black holes is 
of major consequence to the entire field of physics, as they represent one 
of the most extreme configurations of spacetime possible.

As virtually all modern inventions are derived in some way from the study 
of physics, I don't think there's any point trying to

comments.author: stefania1171

comments.text:
+stefania1171

"Mersini-Houghton’s conclusions have already been severely criticized by 
William Unruh, a theoretical physicist from the University of British 
Columbia.

“The [paper] is nonsense,” Unruh said in an email to IFL Science media 
outlet.

“Attempts like this to show that black holes never form have a very long 
history, and this is only the latest. They all misunderstand Hawking 
radiation, and assume that matter behaves in ways that are completely 
implausible,” he claimed.

Quite to the contrary of Mersini-Houghton calculations, Unruh maintains 
that black holes do not emit enough Hawking radiation to lose mass to avoid 
formation of a black hole.

“It would take 10^53 (1 followed by 53 zeros) times the age of the universe 
to evaporate,” Unruh explained, adding that it is a common mistake for 
those who do not understand Hawking’s radiation theory in full, that the 
“outgoing energy back closer and closer to the horizon of the black hole, 
where its energy density gets larger and larger,” he said.

“Unfortunately, explicit calculations of the energy density near the 
horizon show it is really, really small instead of being large. Those 
calculations were already done in the 1970s. To call a bad speculation ‘has 
been proven mathematically’ is, shall we say, an overstatement,” Unruh 
concluded."

Next time, read the article completely before just looking at titles. Call 
me when this ends up in a peer reviewed physics journal.

comments.author: stefania1171

comments.text:
+stefania1171 first off, it's a wormhole, not a black hole.  There's a 
difference.  It is well known that at the center of our galaxy, there is a 
supermassive black hole,  which we can not see, but have major evidence 
supporting it, like stars orbiting faster the closer they are to the 
center, meaning the has to be a large gravitational pull there.  Unless you 
have reason to prove otherwise, it's a black hole.  The original argument 
was that how can we know what a black hole or wormhole looks like if we've 
never seen it?  Well, we have equations that take in all the stimuli and 
effects of a black hole/wormhole, and these equations were put to use by 
the co-producer who is a scientist, and they were used to make a cgi 
effect, which is now being heavily regarded as the closest we have been to 
recreating a black hole and observing it.
comments.author: Angel Pygs
